reference: This image depicts Kaposi sarcoma, a skin disease characterized by purple, irregular, and sometimes ulcerated lesions. It is caused by human herpes virus and is more prevalent in immunocompromised individuals. The prognosis varies based on the type, with the classic type having a good prognosis, while the African and AIDS-associated types have a poor prognosis. Treatment options include chemotherapy and immunotherapy.

reference: This image describes acrocyanosis, a condition where the skin turns blue or gray due to poor circulation, commonly affecting the hands and feet. It is more significant in the distal vasculature compared to the whole hand or foot. The most common associated condition is anorexia nervosa, and treatment involves treating the underlying eating disorder and avoiding medications. A simple bedside test is to lift the affected area, which can help reduce redness.
